title: Whatâ€™s that ringing in your ears? - Marc Fagelson

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the perception of a noise like ringing, buzzing, hissing, or clicking that occurs without any external source of sound?

options.label: B
options.text: To modify the tuning knob to get a clearer signal

options.label: C
options.text: To establish the neural code for silence

multiple-choice.question: What is subjective tinnitus?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A symptom associated with every known ear disorder

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where a person hears a sound that is not present

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where a person's brain modifies their baseline for silence

options.label: A
options.text: To eliminate the tinnitus sound completely

options.label: B
options.text: To mask the tinnitus sound with other noises

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the loudness of the tinnitus sound

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses soothing, complex auditory signals to distract the brain from the tinnitus sound

options.label: B
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses sounds with the same frequency as the patient's tinnitus to occupy the neurons that would otherwise deliver the tinnitus signal

options.label: C
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses white noise to mask the tinnitus sound

options.label: D
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses music to mask the tinnitus sound

options.label: B
options.text: Tinnitus can exacerbate these conditions such as PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a cure for tinnitus

options.label: C
options.text: To help people understand tinnitus and develop neutral associations with the sound

options.label: A
options.text: A person hears a sound that is not present

options.label: B
options.text: A person does not hear a sound that is present

options.label: C
options.text: A person's brain becomes more sensitive to sound

options.label: D
options.text: A person's brain becomes less sensitive to sound and modifies their baseline for silence

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the brain's background neural activity in the auditory system?

options.label: B
options.text: To modify the tuning knob to get a clearer signal

options.label: C
options.text: To establish the neural code for silence

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Tinnitus has no relationship with the brain's internal noise

options.label: D
options.text: Tinnitus can cure the brain's internal noise

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of energetic masking in sound therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: To use soothing, complex auditory signals to distract the brain from the tinnitus sound

options.label: B
options.text: To use sounds with the same frequency as the patient's tinnitus to occupy the neurons that would otherwise deliver the tinnitus signal

options.label: C
options.text: To use white noise to mask the tinnitus sound

options.label: D
options.text: To use music to mask the tinnitus sound

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between tinnitus and PTSD?

options.label: C
options.text: Tinnitus has no relationship with PTSD

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of experiencing tinnitus in a sense?

options.label: A
options.text: A person hears a sound that is not present

options.label: B
options.text: A person does not hear a sound that is present

options.label: C
options.text: A person's brain becomes more sensitive to sound

options.label: D

title: When is a pandemic over?

multiple-choice.question: When does the World Health Organization (WHO) declare a pandemic over?

options.label: A
options.text: When the death toll reaches a certain number

options.label: D
options.text: When the infection is mostly contained and rates of transmission drop significantly throughout the world

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the "Delay and Vaccinate" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow people to be exposed to the virus as quickly as possible

options.label: B
options.text: To restrict travel and quarantine infected individuals

options.label: C
options.text: To synchronize responses across the world

options.label: D
options.text: To give research facilities time to produce a vaccine

multiple-choice.question: What is herd immunity, and how is it achieved?

options.label: A
options.text: Herd immunity is achieved when a certain percentage of the population has been vaccinated, and it protects those who have not been vaccinated

options.label: B
options.text: Herd immunity is achieved when the virus is eradicated, and it protects the entire population

options.label: C
options.text: Herd immunity is achieved when the virus spreads quickly and infects a large percentage of the population, and it protects those who have not been infected

options.label: D
options.text: Herd immunity is achieved when a certain percentage of the population has been exposed to the virus and has built up their immune responses

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows people to be exposed to the virus as quickly as possible

options.label: B
options.text: It restricts travel and quarantines infected individuals

options.label: C
options.text: It synchronizes responses across the world and can end a pandemic in just a few months with low loss of life

options.label: D
options.text: It is too slow and may take years to be effective

multiple-choice.question: What is the main disadvantage of the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: It may not be effective if the virus is not completely eradicated

options.label: B
options.text: It may lead to a global catastrophe and widespread destruction

options.label: C
options.text: It requires true and nearly impossible global cooperation

multiple-choice.question: Which strategy is generally considered to be the best option for ending a pandemic?

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccination, assisted by as much global coordination as possible

multiple-choice.question: Why is vaccination considered to be the best option for ending a pandemic?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the fastest way to end a pandemic

options.label: B
options.text: It provides long-lasting immunity and can protect people from future outbreaks

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most cost-effective way to end a pandemic

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of vaccines in protecting people from future outbreaks of the virus?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaccines provide temporary immunity that wears off after a few months

options.label: B
options.text: Vaccines provide long-lasting immunity that can protect people from future outbreaks

options.label: C
options.text: Vaccines do not provide any protection against future outbreaks

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccines can only protect people from severe symptoms, but not from infection

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of a pandemic on society and the economy?

options.label: A
options.text: A pandemic has no impact on society and the economy

options.label: B
options.text: A pandemic leads to widespread destruction and chaos

options.label: C
options.text: A pandemic can lead to breakthroughs in treatment and prevention of symptoms, and can also disrupt most people's lives for a short period of time

options.label: D
options.text: A pandemic can be used to develop new social services and systems that can benefit everyone

multiple-choice.question: What is the legacy of a pandemic, and how can it be used to benefit society?

options.label: A
options.text: A pandemic leaves no legacy and has no impact on society

options.label: B
options.text: A pandemic leads to widespread destruction and chaos, and has no positive impact on society

options.label: C
options.text: A pandemic can lead to breakthroughs in treatment and prevention of symptoms, and can also disrupt most people's lives for a short period of time

options.label: D
options.text: A pandemic can be used to develop new social services and systems that can benefit everyone
